newsitem.title: UK: Euro oil swaps firm, fuel up $1 again, CFDs up 9 c.
newsitem.headline: Euro oil swaps firm, fuel up $1 again, CFDs up 9 c.

text.p: European oil swaps moved slightly higher on Thursday morning but trading was quiet due to a public holiday across much of Europe.
Brent CFDs rose nine cents a barrel for next week's dates to 15 cents under June with the following week three cents up at 17 cents under.

Monthly CFDs were little changed. The balance of May talked 34 cents under the front line Brent futures contract with forward levels at the following levels under the IPE: -25 cents June, -21 cents July, -17 cents 3Q97, -14 cents 4Q97.
Fuel swaps climbed $1 a tonne, extending similar gains made on Wednesday. May barge swaps talked up to $85, dragged higher by firm Singapore swaps around $102.
"There is no market in Europe today so it's just getting dragged up by Singapore and the U.S.," said a trader.
Low sulphur was also strong with levels close to $91 for May and $92.50 on June.
Further forward the shape of the barge market was little changed despite reports on Wednesday of growing Russian exports.
Up to 4.5 million tonnes of Russian fuel is likely to be exported through St Petersburg from May to November this year, a Western trader based at the port told Reuters.
This is well above 1996 but close to the volumes seen in 1995 when peak exports levels hit around one million tonnes in the month of August.
Gasoline firmed $1 a tonne on June swaps which traded at $193.25 and $193.50. May was $1 higher at $194.50 and was partially held back by sluggish physical barges which talked $193 by lunchtime.
Middle distillates were flat although the underlying tone remained weak. Gas oil crack spreads held at $4.30 a barrel (3Q97), $4.85 (4Q97) and $4.70 (1Q98).
